headline: Alabama Fire Crackers
description: This firecracker recipe features saltine crackers soaked overnight in basic pantry spices, including plenty of hot red chili flakes, until fiery hot.

video.description: These spicy crackers are perfect for your next snack spread!
video.name: Alabama Fire Crackers

name: Alabama Fire Crackers

recipeInstructions.text: Place vegetable oil, ranch dressing mix, crushed red pepper flakes, garlic powder, onion powder, and black pepper in a 2-gallon resealable plastic bag. Seal the bag and squeeze with your hands until oil and spices are well combined.

Place crackers into the bag, seal, and turn the bag over to coat crackers with spice mix. Let sit for about 1 hour, then turn again. Repeat several times until crackers are well-coated with spice mix, then allow the bag to sit 8 hours to overnight. Remove crackers and serve.

review.reviewBody: Everyone loves these! I mean EVERYONE LOVES THESE!!!!!! I make them with regular saltines, mini-saltines, and even mini Club crackers. Too good. Caution though that 3 tablespoons of red pepper flakes is very hot and turns off some of the girls. I usually use 1 1/2 T. which seems perfect to me and my friends and families.

We have made these several times. We drive semi and these make a good little driving snack. We love using the mini crackers. Have made them with saltines numerous times. Now we use the mini Club Crackers. They add just a little sweetness to counter the pungent Ranch Dressing mix. And instead of Vegetable oil we use Canola Oil. Just saw another reviewer mention using Italian Dressing mix. I think I will have to try a small batch of those next time.

I loved the taste of these crackers, although I did reduce the amount of oil to a cup. The second time I made these I used oyster crackers for a nice look. They were still good but the pepper flakes didn’t stick as well as they did on the saltines.

my dad loves snacks so he'll be 86 towards Will in January and he loves snacks I like to make him and put them in a decorative jar along with his Christmas present and me and my husband always enjoy crackers as a snack

These are delicious! I used 3/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper instead of red pepper flakes because that's what I had on hand. If you want full amount of heat, use 1 1/2 teaspoons cayenne. I also took another reviewer's advice and used 3/4 cup oil. I tried this recipe with Wheat Thins and Chicken in a Biscuit crackers. Both were really tasty!

Love these so much. I added a box of Cheez Its to the mix with the Saltines for a bit of variety. They are so good. Brought them to work to share and now everyone wants to know when I am bringing more.
Our family loves this recipe. I, however, prefer to use the mini-saltines so they can be eaten like a snack. Always make them to take camping - nice lunch snack with some cheese, salami, etc.

Love love love this recipe. I Make these any time we have a family get together and they are gone by the end of the day. I usually have to make 1/2 of the batch without the red pepper flakes for those that can't handle the heat. They're really good with aged cheddar. Last time I made them I was short a half sleeve of crackers so I added some cheez-its. Amazing.
Halved the recipe (wish I hadn’t!) and in turn, halved again the oil and red pepper flakes. These were awesome and were a huge hit! An addictive snack! Thanks for sharing!

These are super tasty! My friends loved them. I used two envelopes but think I have to cut the salt back somewhere - they were a bit salty. So I'm going to make them again today but use unsalted Premium Crackers and see how those turn out. I took them to our favoite watering hole to see how the bartenders would like them - LOVED THEM. Good snack!
These were horrible. Such a heavy oil coating when put in mouth I just chucked them

I make these every year during the holidays. I use 1 cup of oil and I also add a little more pepper flakes because my little Cajuns like it REALLY spicy. They are good with EVERYTHING but my favorite is with cream cheese and pepper jelly. HOT pepper jelly!! Mais yeah!

Outstanding! I will definitely make again. Great for hostess or Christmas gifts. I went by recipe amounts, added cayenne Pepper, as we like spice, and did use all the oil as I added more crackers. I used Townhouse Italian Herb Flatbread, Italian Four Cheese Cheez-Its and Oyster Crackers. I think next time I will add some nuts. Thank you for a great recipe!
WAY TOO MUCH OIL. I even reduced the amount called for in the recipe to 3/4 cup & it was still too much for the large box of Triscuits I used. Neat idea, but needs some tweaking.

I made it verbatim with the recipe. Couldn't find any 2gal zip bags, but I found I could get 3/4 of a 16oz box in a one gal bag. I didn't cut any ingredients. Just the cracker total. These are great. Pretty hot, but really good with cold beer.
Nice recipe! Nice change from popcorn.
this was a terrible recipe. greasy and fattening. i would rather eat a bag of chips. sorry.
Always a hit with my holiday treats! A nice addition to all the sweets.
So easy and Amazingly Addictive. I was amazed how they stay so crispy. I used Mini saltine crackers so No mess and No crumbs. Just pop them in your mouth. A great party appetizer.
Delicious!
I added powdered cayenne pepper- about 1/2 tsp. for added kick. Sooo good! For variety, worcester sauce and/ or smoked bbq rub would be fantastic! Or even ginger soy this chili!
OMG love these! New family favorite!

I like these! They're great! I will follow some of the other suggestions and reduce the oil amount, and try Italian seasoning next time. I used mini crackers because they are better for snacking, albeit I felt it tasted a little too salty as some others have said. I'll try unsalted crackers too. Great recipe!

Since it was my first time making this I wasn’t about to make a 1 lb box of crackers version the recipe calls for. I did about 33% of a box of crackers. I tried to adjust the quantities, but the package calls for two 1oz packages of dry ranch dressing. I ended up using one package. So, it was a little heavy on that factor - and hence a little salty. Other than that, I’d give it a 5 if recipe directions were followed exactly. It’s nice that you can adjust the red pepper flakes to your heat prefs. You could also substitute cayenne (ground red pepper) to get more even distribution. I’ll make this again.

Made these crackers last night, and they are really, really good. There seems to be a bit more oil and spices in the bag so next time I will add more crackers. Put almost two sleeves in the bag. Can't wait to make them for a get-together!

Great flavor! However after flipping as instructed I baked them on low for a bit to dry them out a short while. 
Second attempt I used cheezits because it's what I had.....a yummy substitute.

I followed the instructions and they came out pretty good! The flavor is great, however they were not all coated because there are so many crackers crammed into one baggie. I left them in the bag for about 12 hours and gently turned the bag every 15 minutes or so. Since this recipe will be super easy to divide I will split it up next time and use two bags with half recipe in each bag. The only down side is I felt they were too salty. I will use salt-free crackers next time.

I love this recipe and make it often. the only adjustment I make is following the comment suggestion of replacing a ranch packet with an Italian packet (regular, zesty, or spicy depending on my mood.) However, last night, I decided to replace the saltines with oyster crackers, pretzels, and dry roasted peanuts as an experiment. Love the way it turned out.

Everyone LOVES!! I cannot keep in the house because I cannot stop having "just a couple"! HA ... Trying to eat healthy. However, very good for a crowd. I am thinking and making for Christmas gifts in cute jars and giving recipe.
A little less oil...but that is our preference...I used 2 and a half cups and it was perfect!!!
These are SOOO good and super easy. I used one box of wheat thins and cut the recipe in half.
These are SOOO good and super easy. I used one box of wheat thins and cut the recipe in half.
I've made this before, but used Orville Redenbacher's Popcorn and Topping Oil instead of vegetable oil. Turned out great. Also use the recipe on pretzels.
I tried it and it was a bag of mush. It has to have some baking directions too. Don't try till you have the rest of the recipe.
My instructor bought some of these to class, these were so good.
The Best! My family loves them.

I normally do not rate a recipe if I make changes, but honestly, the changes I made were so minor that I can't NOT rate this recipe. Can we talk about delicious for a moment?! Yowsa, these are addictive.
The changes I made: I used mini saltine crackers for two reasons 1)mini anything is just more fun and 2) I like a smaller cracker but am not a fan of the way oyster crackers tend to split. I personally think the mini saltines are preferable to the full size for snacking purposes. The only other changes I made were using extra light tasting olive oil (I followed the advice of other reviewers and cut it in half), a pepper blend instead of red pepper flakes (because I ran out), and one packet of ranch and one Italian (because I had them on hand already).
Just the right amount of flavor and crunch. I will most definitely be making these again.

Probably the simplest and cheapest gussied-up snack out there. Here are a few tips for this otherwise tasty recipe: 3T cayenne flakes is more heat than I like; 1T is not enough. Three different grocery stores did not have whole-GRAIN saltines, so I substituted whole-WHEAT. (A few years ago, I found whole grain crackers in grocery stores, but not yesterday.) The whole wheat crackers I bought were kind of crumbly. Next time I'll just use regular saltines. I will also mix the seasonings with the oil in a 4-cup glass measure and drizzle that onto the crackers after the crackers are in the bag - just smooshing and flipping the cracker bag does not mix the oil among the crackers well. The crackers need the overnight hours in the bag to absorb the oil.
After soaking with seasonings I bake mine in the oven to lock it in. Delicious!

I made two adjustments for these. I used Peanut Oil,but a little less of it and after letting it soak overnight I lined them all off on a cookie sheet with paper towels underneath. I then place them in the oven on the warm setting. That does two things, 1)the heat helps cook the spices on to the cracker, 2) the heat and paper towels help push out and absorb the excess oil making them not quite as oily.
I make them all the time. But with Canola Oil

EXCELLENT recipe! I made these last night for a party tonight. I didn't use the ranch dressing, but used fajita instead. It took less than five minutes to put it together. This morning I tried one with my coffee and thought, oh no! I might not be able to stop eating them! This is going to be a favorite recipe of mine especially for gatherings.

EXCELLENT recipe! I made these last night for a party tonight. I didn't use the ranch dressing, but used fajita instead. It took less than five minutes to put it together. This morning I tried one with my coffee and thought, oh no! I might not be able to stop eating them! This is going to be a favorite recipe of mine especially for gatherings.
Love these things I added about 1/4tsp of cayenne and they were great definitely making again
I make these every year but I use Fiesta Ranch powder along with dried peppers and olive oil. I make several bags and pass out at work. Everyone loves them. Its a great treat for Texans!!!!
These are Fantastic, and really live up to their name! I am asked to bring to parties all the time !
Made no changes. Just made them. Will let them sit overnight,like the recipe says. Look forward to tomorrow

My family likes 'hot' foods so I added an additional 1/2 teaspoon cayenne pepper. I can't make them fast enough. An additional tip...if you like them as much as we do, I purchase my crackers at the Dollar General (in Texas) for $1.25...a LOT cheaper than regular grocery store prices.

YES YES YES!!!! Totally a hit. I work in a prison and we were having a pot luck. I wanted to make something that was portable enough that the officers could take it back to their housing units. This hit the spot. The right amount of heat and seasoning. I have made this at least 3 times since finding the recipe and have even used oyster crackers on a batch. Easiest snack to make and oh so good. :-) Thank you for sharing.

I have made this several times. It is always a hit. I have substituted the regular sized crackers with the oyster crackers for snacks and they work as well. Thinking of trying some other types of small crackers. So easy and always popular.
I didn’t think it was that great, and I love crackers. But maybe I just did not pair it with the right food.
Made it with oyster crackers and less oil. Still fantastic!
They were a hit at the office potluck. I only put 1/2 of what the pepper flakes suggested and they were perfect!

Soooo Goood! Ive made these several times now but forget to review. I followed the recipe as written but like others here, i mix the oil and seasonings separately in a bowl then pour over the crackers. i have to stop myself from going into the bag before the 24 hours is up! I thought they were going to be greasy but surprisingly, they are still crispy. the craving for more hit me yesterday so ill be making them this evening. im going to try with ritz, and cheezits too.
I serve these with home made pimento cheese, always a hit! They're so easy to make, you just have to plan ahead.
This Alabama family loved them.
I did not use as much red pepper as given in the recipe. I only used 1 thsp. We liked it.

what a waste of time. They end up looking like broken saltines and you really wouldn't serve them to anyone. They do taste good but there's nothing there to make the spices stick on the crackers and additionally, you'd never serve bare looking saltines to anyone. This is the worst recipe I've made on this site, or really any where. In trying to coat them in the plastic bag, they get broken. I couldn't get anyone to eat them and threw them all out
Super good and I will make again. Family loved them. I didn’t change anything.
Simple to make but plan ahead to get the seasoning absorbed overnight. It was a big hit in our home.

These are my go-to snacks when I want something savory! I have been making them for YEARS. A few pro-tips that will have you snacking on them in about 2 hours, instead of the next day: you CAN use just one cup of oil, and have it work just fine. Use a 2 1/2 gallon ziplock bag for mixing. Once you mix your oil and spices, let the flavors infuse the oil for about half an hour, stirring up the bits from the bottom a few times while you wait. I also like to use white pepper in place of the black pepper. Pour the oil over the crackers in the bag, and when you close it, leave plenty of air in there to shake them around in. Every 15 minutes or so, flip the bag and give it a good shake, then let it rest another 15 minutes. In two hours, from start to finish, you can happily enjoy your treat!!
Wow! Surprisingly good honestly, as I'm not good with spiciness, but this was just the right amount and boy did it really knock it out of the park!

I’ve made these crackers using both the mini saltines as well as oyster crackers. They are wonderful, regardless! Did I mention addicting?! Snap to it and get to creating! Mix it up and try different flavors of dry dip mix. I find mine at local craft shows.
Addictive. I used half ranch dressing and Italian and cut back to 1 1/3 olive oil. . I also put in oven on cookie sheet for 30 minutes at 225.

I've been making these for years since I had it as a kid once on an old hunting lease but I have tweaked the recipe a little. I use a tablespoon of each spice instead of a tsp (still use 3 tbsp of chili flakes) I also add a little cayenne and lemon pepper. I like a lot of heat and a little more zest.

3.28.18 I cut this recipe in half and used fewer red pepper flakes and less oil. Taste is good, but every time you pick up one of these crackers, your fingers get greasy, and that’s with using only 1/3 cup oil. As the recipe submitted mentions, I would think that they’d be a good partner to chili, but I think I’ll stick with my oyster crackers, so I’m not constantly reaching for a napkin to wipe off my fingers.
Made this for New Years! Turned out Great, but next time I will cut back on the oil!!
We used only 1 Tablespoon of red pepper flakes for a bit less heat. We also added 4 Tablespoons of melted butter to the mix. These were a great hit at the New Year's Party

I made these with cheez-it crackers instead this time and added a little more red pepper flakes because of personal preference and they were soooo good. These are great with saltines as I originally tried it but the cheez-it crackers were maybe even better (I'm a cheese addict). Thank you for the recipe, these will be great for snacks, in lunches, and to give to friends and family.
We have made these so many times. I just alter the heat based on who will be snacking with me..They are fabulous just as thr recipe is written.
Last year I made a cracker recipe for the holidays and my family said they wanted spice! So here it is in the recipe, Spice in caps but still has that flavor you want another. Great recipe!

I have made these several times now with only a few changes. I use 100% sunflower oil and I usually make two batches at a time, one with the pepper flakes and one without for those who don't like hot stuff. I have also tried using the Italian dressing but it just doesn't seem to taste right. These are my go to item when I need to "bring a dish" and they are always a hit.

I have been making these for several years and everyone loves them. I use a box of Nabisco Saltines, one packet of ranch and one packet of Italian dressing mix and only 1 cup of oil. I use less red pepper flakes than called for (or sometimes none), because I don't like them too spicy. A great snack and great with chili!

I used Italian dressing mix only because that's what I had. I found them a bit on the salty side but that might be because I did not use Ranch dressing mix. I did like the flavor of these and the next time I make them I will use unsalted crackers.

I followed directions to the letter EXCEPT I cut the oil to 1 cup only and put two sleeves of saltine crackers. They turned out fabulous and was a huge hit at the football get together I went to. Thank you!!!
These are really yummy. I found 1 1/3 c. oil, 1 pkg. ranch dressing mix and 2 Tbsp. red pepper flakes to be enough. 1 2/3 c. oil was to much.

I used only one tablespoon of red pepper flakes and the other 2 tablespoons were ms.dash extra spicy, which isn't that spicy.. was still uncomfortable to eat. I can't imagine 3 tablespoons of red pepper. toooo spicy for all of us. would have been 5 stars without that..
Love these. My guys eat them all the time. Way cheaper than buying the store mix.

Made this many times now. It is one of the most requested recipes. I do not use multi-grain crackers but regular UN-salted top saltine crackers (or it gets too salty). I tried this with Italian packets only and ranch dressing only but my favorite is using both Italian and Ranch dressing packets. The bags really have to be turned every hour, at least 3-4 times, then definitely have to sit for over night. But I found out that leaving them for second night is even better. I made some without following this instruction and the result was completely disaster, so I strongly suggest to turn the bag and don't touch for one or two days.
These crackers are addicting. I did cut back on the red pepper flakes though just a personal preference. Have tried this recipe with pretzels as well. very good.

These crackers are an absolute crowd pleaser! I put all of the crackers in a large cellophane bag meant to wrap gift baskets, tied a knot in the bag and tossed the crackers around about every 15 minutes for an hour. They taste perfect the nxt day (I wouldn't recommend trying them the same day you mix them). I think these will be a staple around my house--I'm not sure how we would ever get tired of them! Just for our personal taste preference I did the following: made sure to purchase "ranch & seasoning mix" (not just the ranch!) , omitted black pepper, only 2 tablespoons of crushed pepper, added 1 tablespoon of cayenne.
Very good! I changed it a little. I used Multi Grain club crackers and added 1/4 cup less of oil and 1 teaspoon less red pepper flakes. They were plenty spicy for us.

I thought I needed to try what I thought would be the worst recipe ever...My curiosity had me on this one

This was amazing. I cut the oil way back and used ceasar dressing pack and a touch of Italian herbs because that is what I had.. 
I will make again for sure
Everyone loved these. A nice snack to have.
i make these all the time tey are so good

Fantastic! I didn't have a 2gallon freezer bag so I split the recipe and used 2 one-gallon bags. I used 2/3 cup of oil in each (1 1/3 c total) and next time will cut it down a little more. But the seasoning was perfect. I took it to work to share. Today coworkers are flagging me down on the street to request more! Definitely a keeper. Thanks for the great recipe.
I also used my homemade ranch mix and half the oil. 2 teaspoons of red pepper was just the right amount of heat for this Minnesota girl!
I've made these for several showers and people really love them, even the guys. Thanks for sharing this recipe!

Do NOT NOT NOT use multigrain or salted top crackers! The multigrain ones were absolutely horrible and the salted tops made them so salty they were almost unbearable! Plain top, everything else the same, and these are WINNERS! They really ARE better after a day. I get requests for these for get togethers, and get asked for the recipe every time. These are a family (and work) favorite.
Great snack and great for soups!

I made this at work and people loved it! After mixing all the spices, I put on a pair of gloves. I rubbed the oil mix gently on to each crackers to make sure the flavor distributed evenly. I did turn the container around once so often. Over night did the magic as well. Most importantly, the crackers never got soggy. I got about 20 thumbs up in one day.

I have made these several times and ALWAYS get rave reviews. The multi-grain crackers stand up better than regular saltines. I was not a fan of the baggie mixer. I found a LARGE bowl at Target with a 4-sided snap on lid that would not leak. I LOVE IT!
It is great for shaking and coating the crackers. Bought one and gave it to a friend with the ingredients and recipe. He was thrilled.

I always make as directed first. I made changes to suit our tastes the second time. Used one package of oyster crackers, 3/4 C. Olive oil, halved everything else. Left them in the bag for two hours (I have patience issues). Then popped them into a 250 degree oven until they began to brown, about 12 minutes. Seasoning mix is excellent.
Love this!

I'm making a 3rd batch now. I used only 2 packs of saltines half a packet of ranch dressing celery salt,along with onion and garlic powder. I left out the pepper and added just a dash of cayenne instead. Family went crazy for them.

Great crackers for oysters or fish dip! 

I had to use ranch dressing and Italian dressing mix es (only had one of each) and it turned out pretty darn good!
One of the best, and easy crowd pleasing recipes ever!

I couldn't imagine these wouldn't be oily, but they weren't. If you think there's too much oil you could brush it on both sides and proceed from there. I have made them two ways. One baked for a bit in the oven, because my crackers were old and stale and the submitted way. Both are excellent. I haven't tried the Italian mix yet, but I would also like to try Dill Pickle mix. These things are the best for a humble old Saltine.
EVERYONE LOVES THEM!!!
